If you haven't played this yet, I have one question for you: WHY? Killing Floor is definitely one of my favorite FPS. It's cool, it's creepy, and it has excellent gunplay. Despite the game's repetitive nature, it's loads of fun! The sheer amount of updates this game has received is also amazing.

Classic cooperative grindhouse horde shooter. If you can stand the campiness, old Unreal Engine quirks and the repetitiveness of its gameplay, it can be very fun.


It's still alive with a halfway decent population despite the development of its sequel, Killing Floor 2. There's not much of a plot, but the Objective Mode maps give you insight and expand on what there is, and the lore can be surprisingly interesting. This is a game for people who want to shoot the hell out of monsters with a healthy layer of cheese, and while that's more or less all there is to the game, the wide variety of maps, perks, difficulties and weapons make sure it doesn't get too stale. The tactical, methodical gameplay at the higher levels also contributes to this for more experienced players.

Killing Floor was born from an Unreal Tournament mod and still uses Unreal Engine 2, which belies a lot of its jankiness and interface/gameplay quirks, although at least it allows for smooth 60 FPS gameplay. The graphics aren't mind-blowing, but are still nice if you turn the settings up, and most maps have a convincingly foreboding, gritty atmosphere - kind of like a grindhouse movie.

The guns, though, are grand. Tripwire Interactive also made the WWII games Red Orchestra & Rising Storm, and they put a lot of work into their video game guns. Killing Floor's guns sound and feel excellent, very smooth compared to some other aspects of the game, and there is a pretty wide array to choose from even without the DLC guns. A fair bit of the game's lasting appeal may be due to how satisfying they are to use.

There are three DLC weapon packs that give new guns, the others being gun reskins or new characters, but the guns themselves are either mostly balanced or actually on the weak side. This is far from a pay-to-win game, although it's still a bit annoying seeing someone with a nice gun that you can't have unless you ask them to drop it. Since the DLC is uniformly overpriced and mostly comprised of cosmetic skins, wait for a sale if you want any of the actual weapon DLC.

KF's voice acting is indeed cheesy: there are two voices stretched across most of the game's characters, including most of the DLC ones, and about 45% of their voice lines are British slang by volume. The music is mostly industrial/ambient metal that meshes fairly well with the game's tone. Don't be fooled, though: this game [i]can[/i] approach survival horror, especially when you're on the run with little ammunition and half of your team dead.


Killing Floor is great for what it is, but it's repetitive by nature. Its sequel, while having a wider color palette, higher production values and a faster pace, is the same basic concept. Any choice between the two for newcomers will probably boil down to whether they like the gritty yet somewhat campy aesthetic of KF1 or the more sci-fi aesthetic of KF2, as well as how powerful their computer is. The cheese and the jank can even grow on you if you end up playing the game enough.

As to a comparison with Left 4 Dead, I'll just say that the Killing Floor community is definitely more welcoming. I'm not entirely sure why; maybe it's the fact that there's only a versus mode in the sequel, and even there it's not actually played often. Maybe Source engine gamers and Unreal engine gamers are simply different. Who knows?

Achievement hunters be warned: there's a broken achievement that was a tie-in to another game, and the devs have no intention of fixing it. I count myself lucky I earned it back in the day...

Awesome game. Nothing like shooting a man with a chainsaw instead of an arm 5 times in the face with a shotgun until he charges at you, then you pull out your double barrel shotgun and blow his head into at least 20 different bits. And not only that, the second the pellets hit his head the game goes into slow motion, so you can enjoy every milisecond of it. All while your best friends are right by your side. Definitely worth every cent.

The Killing Floor is a First Person Shooter where the player attempts to survive, either in solo or co-op, to waves of mutated specimens. The variety of weapons is decent and there are multiple classes called "Perks" to give you bonuses as you level them up. There are also different difficulties ranging from easy to the insane mode of Hell on Earth.

Now, if you excuse me, I shall be hunting the Patriarch with a Crossbow. (10/10)

Not your mother's Zombie Survival game. Haven't played enough to really rave about it, but I've played L4D1&2 extensively and thought Killing Floor wouldn't stand a chance. How wrong was I? This game holds its own amongst the other shooters of its kind. Definitely a buy!

Great survival game. You get a ton of official maps, decent sized weapon stock and a variety of enemies. Online is a blast, getting through a map with 5 other players is fun but challenging. Oftentimes one wrong decision can lead to you being cornered and torn to pieces. The game has a slightly steep learning curve but once you get the hang of it, the amount of satisfaction you get from beating the final boss is great. Despite its release several years back, it is periodically updated with new weapons, maps and theme events such as Christmas and Halloween. Definitely worth it for the price tag.
Un survival hyper innovant, à mi-chemin entre fallout et Left4Dead.
